text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

During Fiscal Year 2014, the Appeals International Penalty Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) was reorganized to incorporate all post-assessed International penalties worked in Appeals. In this revision of IRM 8.11.5, the format, structure and content were significantly rearranged and updated to provide a comprehensive resource of the International penalties process.
) Updated IRM to include editorial changes. (
) Deleted content from IRM
, International Penalty – Chapter
Appeals Procedures , and replaced it with new IRM
, Introduction of International Penalties, to more accurately reflect international penalties most often worked in Appeals. (
) Added new IRM
, Introduction of International Penalties which includes new content such

Added new IRM 8.11.5.1, Introduction of International Penalties which includes new content such as an overview, purpose, and most commonly appealed International penalties; explanation and reference to International penalties subject to deficiency procedures; a reference to general information in IRM 20.1.9, Penalty Handbook-International Penalties; settlement authority; premature referral guidance; related case files; collection activity; PENAP procedures of international assessed penalties; Form 13381 referral guidance; penalty relief; and a reference to acronyms used in Appeals.
Moved information from IRM 8.11.5.2, International Penalty – Accelerated Appeals Consideration, to IRM 8.11.5.14, International Penalty – Accelerated Appeals Consideration.
Added new IRM 8.11.5.2, IRC 6038 Information Reporting with Respect to Foreign Corporations and Partnerships (Form 5471). Added the following new subsections:

IRM Subsection Title IRM 8.11.5.2.1 Reporting and Filing Require- ments for IRC 6038 IRM 8.11.5.2.2 New Receipt Procedures for Appeals Technical Employees IRM 8.11.5.2.3 Penalty Relief IRM 8.11.5.2.4 Closing Procedures

Deleted information from IRM 8.11.5.4, Overview of Accelerated Appeals Procedures - International Penalties, and incorporated relevant portions in new IRM 8.11.5.14, International Penalty – Accelerated Appeals Consideration.
Added new IRM 8.11.5.4, IRC 6038B Notice of Certain Transfers to Foreign Persons. Added the following new subsections:

This IRM Section is for post assessed international penalties and is not appli- cable to International Penalties subject to Deficiency Procedures. The following international penalties are subject to deficiency procedures. See IRM
, Deficiency Procedures, for procedures relating to those penalties subject to deficiency procedures.

This IRM Section is for post assessed international penalties and is not appli- cable to International Penalties subject to Deficiency Procedures. The international penalties are subject to deficiency procedures. See IRM 20.1.1.4.2, Deficiency Procedures, for procedures relating to those penalties subject to deficiency procedures.

) General Information – For general information on International penalties worked by Compliance see IRM
, Penalty Handbook, International Penalties. (

) Settlement Authority - The authority to settle appeals of assessed penalties consistent with the authority to settle all other issues in Appeals. Settlement authority has not been re-delegated to Appeals Officers for International penalties. (

) Premature Referrals - An International penalty must be assessed before routing the case to Appeals. If the penalty is not assessed, the Appeals Technical Employee (ATE) will close the case and return it to the originating function as a premature referral.

) Premature Referrals - An International penalty must be assessed before routing the case to Appeals. If the penalty is not assessed, the Appeals Technical Employee (ATE) will close the case and return it to the originating function as a premature referral. Note: IRM
) and IRC
requires Managers approve the Interna- tional penalty case control, sign notice letters, and approve the penalty by signing Form
prior to closing the penalty case file from amination. Automatically assessed penalties from Service Centers will not include Form
as they are excepted from approval requirement per §

) Related Case Files – A case may include multiple case files: penalty case and related income tax case files. Each penalty and income tax case file will be assigned a separate work unit number and may be routed separately to Appeals. All related case files should be consolidated under one Appeals Officer, International Specialist. (

) Collection Activity - While the case is in Appeals, it’s the taxpayer’s ity to communicate with the Collection function about the status of their case Appeals. Note: The Appeals Officer will assist a taxpayer in providing a collection contact person if the Taxpayer receives collection notices, and a collection has not been assigned to the Taxpayer’s case. (
) Penalty Appeal (PENAP) procedures generally apply to assessed penalties. Refer to IRM
, Penalty Appeals (PENAP) for additional information. (
) Form

, Technical Guidance Referrals - During the preliminary review, ATE checks the Domestic & International Issue Locator for a list of Interna- tional penalties that are designated as an Appeals Coordinated Issue (ACI) an Emerging Issue. It is the responsibility of the ATE to prepare and forward referral, through their ATM, to Specialty Operations on Form
upon receipt of the case. Note: See IRM
, Review and Concurrence - Appeals Officer’s ity, for procedures. (

) Penalty Consideration - Appeals considers applicable statutory, regulatory, judicial guidance relating to the specific penalty. Appeals may also consider “hazards of litigation” when resolving International penalty cases. Appeals clearly document the reason for a penalty abatement in an Appeals Case Memorandum. The Appeals Case Memorandum should document the facts

Penalty Consideration

Appeals considers applicable statutory, regulatory, and judicial guidance relating to the specific penalty. Appeals may also consider the “hazards of litigation” when resolving International penalty cases. Appeals must clearly document the reason for a penalty abatement in an Appeals Case Memorandum. The Appeals Case Memorandum should document the facts

and circumstances including clear justification for partial abatement and the specific hazards of litigation supporting abatement of the penalty. Note: The First Time Abatement (FTA) administrative waiver is not applicable to International Penalties addressed in IRM
) Reasonable Cause – Reasonable cause provisions are evaluated in tion with the guidelines, principles, and evaluating factors identified in IRM
, Introduction and Penalty Relief, as well as, the applicable IRC sections, Treasury regulations, and judicial guidance. See the Exhibit in IRM
, Reasonable Cause Relief, for a listing of penalties that qualify for sonable cause relief. Note: The
Offshore Voluntary Disclosure Initiative (OVDI) removed former FAQ
and replaced it with a reasonable cause requirement for penalty relief consideration. (
) Acronyms - Generally, definitions of terms used in the Manual are with the material where the term is discussed. See the Exhibit in IRM
, Terms Used in Appeals, for a list and the definitions of common terms used Appeals. (
) New Receipt and Closing Procedures for CDP – For any penalties in IRM
that come to Appeals in Collection Due Process, the ATE refer to IRM
, Liability Issues and Relief from Liability, for liability chal- lenges and guidance. (

If the Category 1 Taxpayer elects accelerated pre-payment consideration of these penalties, it will be the taxpayer’s only opportunity to contest that penalty before Appeals. Therefore, if the Category 1 Taxpayer disagrees with the results of an accelerated appeal, the taxpayer will not receive any addi- tional Appeals consideration before or after paying that penalty.
Note: Non-accelerated post-assessed pre-payment appeal rights are available for all other taxpayers hereinafter designated as Category 2 taxpayers.

If the Category

Taxpayer is eligible for accelerated consideration and does not appeal the above international penalty before payment on an accelerated basis, the taxpayer may dispute the penalty before Appeals under standard claim procedures following payment.
If a Category 1 taxpayer is eligible for accelerated consideration and is not provided an opportunity to appeal the international penalty during the ex-
amination on an accelerated basis, the taxpayer may dispute the penalty before Appeals on a post-assessment, pre-payment, non-accelerated basis under standard Appeal procedures.

Once the case has been identified as an accelerated appeal, Compliance contact the Appeals International Specialist Coordinator (AISC) for on where to send the case. AISC information can be found on the Appeals Case Routing page. See the “International” tab on the Appeals Website at http://appeals.web.irs.gov/. Compliance will take action to suspend/stay all Collection activity before sending the penalty case file to Appeals. The AISC facilitates the expeditious case assignment, coordination, and tion of AAP International Penalty cases within Appeals. Within
business days of Compliance contacting Appeals, the Technical cialist will take the following actions: (cid:
) Contact the appropriate Appeals Team Manager (ATM) to identify the or Technical Specialist who will be assigned the case. (cid:
) Identify the APS Unit responsible for establishing the case file on ACDS. (cid:
) Notify Compliance where to send the case file, including the address ATM’s name to ensure prompt handling of the case. (cid:

) Send a secure email to APS Manager, the employee assigned the case and their ATM with the following information: a. Taxpayer’s Name, address and TIN; b. Power of Attorney’s (POA) Name and address; c. Tax Periods; d. Statute Date for each tax period; e. IRC Penalty Code Section(s); f. Dollar Amount of Penalty for each Tax Period; and g. Date of the protest.

Accelerated International Penalty (AAP) cases are high priority cases. Appeals will complete consideration of AAP cases within 120 days of receipt.
Within 5 business days of receipt of the case file, the appropriate ATCL and/or Technical Specialist will take the following actions:
(cid:
) Verify that the penalty was assessed and update the statute as (cid:
) Verify tax periods and dollar amounts. (cid:
) Confirm that the uniform acknowledgement letter was mailed to the taxpayer and/or authorized representative. (cid:
) Verify the ACDS feature codes AI, IT and IC are on the system. If the feature codes are missing, update the system through CARATS. (cid:
) Check the IDRS command code TXMOD to be sure collection activity is suspended.
(cid:
) Prepare the closing documents (Form
, the ACM, and any agreement forms). (cid:

should include the following instructions to APS in the Special Remarks section: “EXPEDITE CLOSING REQUIRED --- ACCOUNT AD- JUSTMENTS MUST BE DONE IMMEDIATELY”. (cid:
